subject: -Djava.ext.dirs issue?
msgSnippet: Hi, I have a problem where if I specify the java ext directory, JUnit is unable to find my test class.  Whereas, if I just use classpath , everything is
messageBody:
Hi,

I have a problem where if I specify the java "ext" directory, JUnit is unable to find my test class. Whereas, if I just use "classpath", everything is fine. Since my tests will ultimately depend on a number of 3rd party libraries, I really want to just use the "ext" directory approach.

For example:

java -classpath /home/cowan/src/atst/lib/java/classes -Djava.ext.dirs=/home/cowan/src/atst/lib/java/ext org.junit.runner.JUnitCore atst.cs.test.TestAll

this ends up with
JUnit version 4.7
Could not find class: atst.cs.test.TestAll

The strange thing is that if I use the verbose flag on java, it even logs that it successfully loaded the TestAll class from the appropriate directory before later displaying the error.

If I modify the command line to:

java -classpath /home/cowan/src/atst/lib/java/classes:/home/cowan/tools/junit4.7/junit.jar org.junit.runner.JUnitCore atst.cs.test.TestAll

everything works as expected.

Does anyone know why -Djava.ext.dirs seems to cause JUnit to malfunction? (I've only tried this with JUnit 4.7)

Thanks,
Bruce
